image.caption: Image courtesy of Library of Congress

profileText: A Representative from South Carolina; born in Charleston, S.C., January 3, 1834; received a limited schooling; employed as shipping clerk in 1850; member of a convention of the Friends of Equal Rights at Charleston in 1865 and was deputed to present the memorial there framed to Congress; member, State house of representatives, 1868-1869; member of the State constitutional convention in 1868 and 1869; Lieutenant Governor of South Carolina in 1870; president of the Southern States Convention at Columbia in 1871; delegate to the Republican National Convention in 1872; elected as a Republican to the Forty-third Congress (March 4, 1873-March 3, 1875); United States internal-revenue collector for the second district of South Carolina in 1875 and 1876; died in Charleston, S.C., on August 17, 1882; interment in Unity Friendship Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: "Alonzo Jacob Ransier" in Black Americans in Congress, 1870-2007. Prepared under the direction of the Committee on House Administration by the Office of History & Preservation, U.S. House of Representatives. Washington: Government Printing Office, 2008.
Holt, Thomas. "Ransier, Alonzo Jacob." In Dictionary of American Negro Biography, edited by Rayford W. Logan and Michael R. Winston. New York: W.W. Norton and Co., 1982.
Ransier, Alonzo Jacob. Civil Rights. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1874.

researchRecord.name: In the Lillian Ransier Wright Papers, 1945-1995, 0.25 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: The papers contain information on Reconstruction Era Africa-American politicians, specifically Alonzo Jacob Ransier.
